hedline.hl1: Few Watched, and Not for Very Long

abstract.p: Television ratings for first night of Republican National Convention indicate only small fraction of total television audience watched prime-time portion of event (S)

block.p: Television ratings for the first night of the Republican National Convention indicated that only a small fraction of the total television audience watched the prime-time portion of the event.

On ABC and CBS, the two broadcast networks that offered just an hour of prime-time coverage each, only about 13 million total viewers tuned in, or about 15 percent of the total television audience. And on CBS, which interrupted its convention coverage for a repeat of a segment of its newsmagazine ''48 Hours,'' on the subject of medical experiments on human patients, about half the audience left when the network shifted to pure convention coverage at 10:30 p.m.
Television ratings for the first night of the Republican National Convention indicated that only a small fraction of the total television audience watched the prime-time portion of the event.

On ABC and CBS, the two broadcast networks that offered just an hour of prime-time coverage each, only about 13 million total viewers tuned in, or about 15 percent of the total television audience. And on CBS, which interrupted its convention coverage for a repeat of a segment of its newsmagazine ''48 Hours,'' on the subject of medical experiments on human patients, about half the audience left when the network shifted to pure convention coverage at 10:30 p.m.
In 1996, the Republicans' opening night attracted an average audiece of 4 million households for the big three networks, a 26 percent decline from the 1992 beginning of the G.O.P. convention.

On the three all-news cable channels, a total of 2.4 million viewers watched the evening convention events. CNN had the biggest audience, 1.2 million, compared with 676,000 for Fox News and 516,000 for MSNBC.
